sen.j: 本禅寺（ほんぜんじ）は、法華宗陣門流の京別院。
sen.e: Honzen-ji Temple is a branch temple in Kyoto Jinmon lineage of Hokke sect.
Honzen-ji Temple is a branch temple in the Kyoto Jinmon lineage of the Hokke sect.
Honzen-ji Temple is a branch temple in the Kyoto Jinmon lineage of the Hokke sect.

sen.j: 山号を光了山（こうりょうさん）と号する。
sen.e: Sango (name of a group of Buddhist temples) is Koryosan.
Its sango (name of a group of Buddhist temples) is Koryosan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Koryosan.

sen.j: 応永13年（1406年）、門祖日陣創建。
sen.e: The temple was built by 門祖Nichijin in 1406.
The temple was built in 1406 by 門祖Nichijin.
The temple was built in 1406 by monso (founder) Nichijin.

sen.j: 塔頭が四院ある（心城院、詮量院、玄妙院、円龍院）。
sen.e: There are four in of tatchu. (sub-temples in the site of main temple) (Shinjo-in Temple, Senryo-in Temple, Genmyo-in Temple, Enryo-in Temple)
sen.cmt: 円龍院→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: There are four in of tatchu (sub-temples on the site of the main temple): Shinjo-in Temple, Senryo-in Temple, Genmyo-in Temple and Enryo-in Temple.
There are four in of tatchu (sub-temples on the site of the main temple): Shinjo-in Temple, Senryo-in Temple, Genmyo-in Temple and Enryo-in Temple.

sen.j: 法華宗陣門流（総本山は越後国三条長久山本成寺
sen.e: Kyoto Jinmon lineage of Hokke sect (Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) is Chokyuzan Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province.)
The Kyoto Jinmon lineage of the Hokke sect (Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) is Chokyuzan Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province).
The Kyoto Jinmon lineage of the Hokke sect (Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) is Chokyuzan Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province).

sen.j: <現、新潟県三条市>）の近畿地方での別院（京別院、上別院）。
sen.e: It is a branch temple in Kinki district ((current Sanjo City, Nigata Prefecture) branch temple in Kyoto, 上別院)
sen.cmt: 上別院→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: It's a branch temple in the Kinki district ((the present-day Sanjo City, Nigata Prefecture) branch temple in Kyoto, 上別院).
It's a branch temple in the Kinki district (the present-day Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture) branch temple in Kyoto, 上別院).

sen.j: 宗祖日蓮の随身仏と言われる金銅立像釈尊が立像堂（りゅうぞうどう）に有る。
sen.e: There is 金銅立像釈尊 in 立像堂, which said to be 随身仏 of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren.
sen.cmt: 金銅立像釈尊 立像堂、随身仏→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: There is 金銅立像釈尊 in 立像堂, which is said to be 随身仏 of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren.
There is a gilt bronze standing statue of Shakyamuni in Ryuzo-do Hall, which is said to be 随身仏 of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren.
sen.cmt: 金銅立像釈尊→a gilt bronze standing statue of Shakyamuni立像堂→Ryuzo-do Hall

sen.j: 室町時代の天文法難後、後奈良天皇より綸旨（りんじ）を賜り、勅願寺となった。
sen.e: After Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) in the Muromachi period, Honjec-ji Temple received rinji (the Emperor's command) from Emperor Gonara to became chokugan-ji. (temple built at the order of the emperor)

Following Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) in the Muromachi period, Honjec-ji Temple received rinji (the Emperor's command) from Emperor Gonara to became chokugan-ji (a temple built at the order of the emperor).

Following Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) in the Muromachi period, Honzen-ji Temple received rinji (the Emperor's command) from Emperor Gonara to became chokugan-ji (a temple built at the order of the emperor).

sen.j: 天保10年（1839年）には有栖川宮家の祈願所となった。
sen.e: In 1839 the temple became Arisugawanomiya family's place for prayer.
In 1839, the temple became the Arisugawanomiya family's place of prayer.
In 1839, the temple became the Arisugawanomiya family's place of prayer.

sen.j: 洛中法華21ヶ寺のひとつ。
sen.e: It is one of the temple out of twenty-one temples of Rakuchu-Hokke sect.
It is one of 21 temples of the Rakuchu-Hokke sect.
It is one of 21 temples of the Rakuchu-Hokke sect.

sen.j: 豊臣秀頼が鋳造し、徳川家康が大坂の役で陣鐘として用い、大久保彦左衛門が奉納したとされる梵鐘。
sen.e: There is a bronze bell (temple bell) which said to be casted by Hideyori TOYOTOMI, and was used by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as a gong in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka), and was dedicated to the temple by Hikozaemon OKUBO.

The bronze bell (temple bell) is said to have been cast by Hideyori TOYOTOMI and used by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as a gong in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka); it was dedicated to the temple by Hikozaemon OKUBO.

The bronze bell (temple bell) is said to have been cast by Hideyori TOYOTOMI and used by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as a gong in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka); it was dedicated to the temple by Hikozaemon OKUBO.

sen.j: 大久保彦左衛門、画家岸駒（がんく）、拝匠梅室（ばいしつ）の墓が有る。
sen.e: There is cemetery of Hikozaemon OKUBO, an artist, Ganku, 拝匠, Baisitsu.
This is the cemetery of Hikozaemon OKUBO, an artist, Ganku, 拝匠 and Baisitsu.
This is the cemetery of Hikozaemon OKUBO, an artist, Ganku, 拝匠 and Baishitsu.

sen.j: 歴代には日覺大僧正などの名僧が多数。
sen.e: There were many successive, famous monks such as 日覺 who was well known, successive daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order).
There were many successive, famous monks such as 日覺, who was well known, along with successive aisojo (Buddhist priests of the highest order).
There were many successive, famous monks such as Nikkaku, who was well known, along with successive daisojo (Buddhist priests of the highest order).
sen.cmt: 日覺→Nikkaku 一般的な読みとしましたスペル

sen.j: 宗祖日蓮から、日朗（六老僧）、日印（鎌倉殿中問答の勝者）、日静（上杉氏
sen.e: The dharma lineage started from the founder of a religious sect, Nichiren, followed by Nichiro (Rokuroso), Nichiin (the winner of Kamakura denchu mondo Dialogue), Nichijo (originated from the Uesugi clan)
sen.cmt: 六老僧、 鎌倉殿中問答→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: The dharma lineage started with the founder of a religious sect, Nichiren, followed by Nichiro (Rokuroso), Nichiin (the winner of Kamakura denchu mondo dialogue), and Nichijo (who originated from the Uesugi clan).

The dharma lineage started with the founder of a religious sect, Nichiren, followed by Nichiro (Rokuroso), Nichiin (the winner of Kamakura denchu mondo dialogue), and Nichijo (who originated from the Uesugi clan).

sen.j: <藤原北家系>出身、後に除歴）、日陣（門祖）と流れる法脈である。
sen.e: (the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan line), later being removed from the successive chief priest), Nichijin. (Monso)
(The Northern House of the Fujiwara clan line), later removed from the succession of chief priests), Nichijin (Monso).
((The Northern House of the Fujiwara clan line), later removed from the succession of chief priests), Nichijin (Monso)).

sen.j: 立像堂（りゅうぞうどう）の宗祖日蓮の念持仏｢立像釈迦牟尼仏｣は､年二回､万人講（4月上旬）と御会式（おえしき）（10月13日）の時において、御開帳される｡
sen.e: The Gokaicho of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren's nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), 'standing statue of Shakamuni Butsu' in Ryudoxo is exhibit to the public twice a year, once in 万人講(early April) and other time in Oeshiki (a Buddhist (memorial) service in Nichiren sect) (October 13).
sen.cmt: 万人講→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: The Gokaicho of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren's nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), 'standing statue of Shakamuni Butsu' in Ryudoxo is exhibited to the public twice each year, once in 万人講 (early April) and again in Oeshiki (a Buddhist (memorial) service in the Nichiren sect, held on October 13).

The Gokaicho of the founder of the religious sect, Nichiren's nenjibutsu (a small statue of Buddha kept beside the person), 'standing statue of Shakyamuni Butsu' in Ryuzo-do Hall is exhibited to the public twice each year, once in Manninko (early April) and again in Oeshiki (a Buddhist (memorial) service in the Nichiren sect, held on October 13).

sen.j: 京都府京都市上京区寺町通広小路通 (京都市)上ル北之辺町394番地（京都御所の北東）
sen.e: 394 Kitanobe machi, Hirokoji-dori (Kyoto City) noboru, Teramachi dori, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture (north east of Kyoto Imperial Palace)
It is located at 394 Kitanobe machi, Hirokoji-dori (Kyoto City) noboru, Teramachi dori, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture (northeast of Kyoto Imperial Palace)
It is located at 394 Kitanobe machi, Hirokoji-dori (Kyoto City) noboru, Teramachi dori, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture (northeast of Kyoto Imperial Palace).

sen.j: 京都御所の清和院御門を出て、寺町通を少し北に進むと、道の東側に南から境内に｢紫式部邸宅遺跡｣がある廬山寺､｢身代り不動｣が有名な清浄華院､本禅寺の三寺が並ぶ。
sen.e: After exiting from Seiwa-in Gomon Gate of Kyoto Imperial Palce and go up to the north for a while from Teramachi dori, there are three famous temples, Rozan-ji Temple where the remains of Murasakishikibu's villa on the east side of the street, and the south side to the precincts of the temple, Shojoke-in Temple, which is famous for Migawarifudo and Honzen-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 身代り不動→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: After exiting from Seiwa-in Gomon Gate of Kyoto Imperial Palace and heading north for a while from Teramachi-dori, there are three famous temples: Rozan-ji Temple, where the remains of Murasakishikibu's villa are found on the east side of the street, and the south side to the precincts of the temple, Shojoke-in Temple, which is famous for Migawarifudo and Honzen-ji Temple.

After exiting from Seiwa-in Gomon Gate of Kyoto Imperial Palace and heading north for a while from Teramachi-dori, there are three famous temples: Rozan-ji Temple, where the remains of Murasakishikibu's villa are found on the east side of the street, and the south side to the precincts of the temple, Shojoke-in Temple, which is famous for Migawarifudo and Honzen-ji Temple.

sen.j: かつて、日陣創建時は四条通堀川通に有り、天文法難以後、日覚大僧正の時に西陣の方四町の地に移る。
sen.e: It used to be located on Shijo dori horikawa dori, and it was moved to 方四町in Nichijin after Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) during Nichikaku daisojo was in power.
sen.cmt: 方四町→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: It was once located on Shijo-dori horikawa-dori, but it was moved to 方四町in Nichijin after Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) during the time in which Nichikaku daisojo was in power.
It was once located on Shijo-dori horikawa-dori, but it was moved to 方四町 in Nishijin after Tenbun-honan (Tenbun Hokke War) during the time in which Nichikaku daisojo was in power.

sen.j: 天正19年（1591年）、現在地に移る。
sen.e: In 1591 it moved to the current place.
In 1591 it moved in 1591 to the site it now occupies.
In 1591 it moved to the site it now occupies.
